Problem:
Consider the heat equation \\(u_t = u_{xx}\\), governing the temperature distribution u(x,t) in a rod along x axis. We consider the impact of an initial temperature distribution manipulated by the function \\(g(u) = Au + h\\), where A is a constant and h is a constant function.

If \\( g(u) \\) is applied to an initial temperature distribution \\( u_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\(u_t = u_{xx}\\) without further intervention, will \\( u(x, t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( u_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\(u_t = u_{xx}\\)?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( g(u) = Au + h \\) alters the initial condition of the temperature distribution, and this modified initial condition will evolve differently under the heat equation. The linear transformation and the addition of the constant function h generally change the temperature evolution.
